thread.title: Market Engine secures Royal Mail investment |
thread.title_full: Market Engine secures Royal Mail investment | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: Market Engine secures Royal Mail investment |
text:
The cloud-based retail software is designed for Western brands looking to get a foothold in international markets, especially China, through a fully translated online shopfront.
The platform claims to simplify cross-border trade by translating text content, images and price points from English into Chinese, enabling brands to manage multiple digital shopfronts across China’s largest e-commerce sites, such as Alibaba’s Tmall, and sell directly to Chinese consumers.
Market Engine chairman Adrian Giles said the investment would propel the company’s continued expansion efforts and aid further development of its proprietary platform.
“Royal Mail’s investment represents a significant vote of confidence in our technology and business model,” he said.
Market Engine is also working with several national postal services including Australia Post, Canada Post and PostNord, which make the software available to local merchants for use. “The platform automatically calculates all third-party fees, taxes and Customs duty etc. Merchants can see in real time what the status of the orders are, including dispatched right through to delivered or paid,” Market Engine co-founder Nathan Ruff told The Australian.
According to Mr Ruff, pairing the platform with the postal service’s extensive distribution network “removes the traditional barriers of selling products overseas”.
While there are companies based in China that offer a similar service, the Melbourne based start-up has carved out a niche with Australian businesses interested in selling their wares directly to the Chinese customer where they can control price, product and quality.
“Our ‘aha’ moment was talking to Australian brands and realising how much product they estimated was going through grey channels into China,” Mr Ruff said.
According to Mr Ruff, it took 20 months to develop the platform and bolster the headcount in China. Since then, the company has doubled in employee size and is about to open an office in Canada.
“We are also working with about 50 Australian businesses to sell into China, and our first global brand, Ecostore, is about to be launched.”
